answers.answer: I have some guesses - but it be much easier for you to call the doctor and ask the diagnosis.  THen you can post back if you have questions still.  I always write it down for the patient.MJK MD

question: I'm a 51 year old male with no history of eye problems, diabetes, glaucoma, etc.  About a week ago I noticed a shadow in the peripheral vision of my right eye which turned out to be a spot of "lost vision".  I went to the eye doctor, who said she saw a "white spot" on my retina that would explain the condition.  She said this was idiopathic something that may resolve itself and she seemed unconcerned.  She was gone so fast that I did not ask the follow-up questions that I should have.  Several days later, it seems the vision may be returning to this spot, but now straight lines appear to be bent in this area of my peripheral vision.  Any idea what my "ideopathic" condition is?  Should I go back to the doc?PT in Texas
title: Anomalies in my peripheral vision
